titleStmt.title: The resolution of the Prince of Wales, concerning the landing of his army in the Isle of Loving-land, within the county of Suffolk, and his propositions to all Englishmen, concerning his engagement for King, city, & kingdom against the army, & to fight for their liberties, freedom & priviledges. Likevvise, the further proceedings of the Royall Navie, under his Highness the D. of York, and the declaration of the seamen in the Isle of VVight and Portsmouth, concerning the King [sic] Majesty and the Fleet Royall. 1648.
titleStmt.author: Burdet, John.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: PropoÅ¿itions from his HighneÅ¿Å¿e the Prince of Wales, agreed upon at a Generall Councell aboard the Royall Navie, by the Lord Culpepper, the Lord Ruthin, the Lord Gerrard, and Sir John Bartley.
div.p:
HAving received information of the Prince of Wales intentions and ReÅ¿olu â¢ ion to land at Yarmouth, with his forces, The Ci â¢ y of Norw â¢ ch, the Town of Attlebury, and other parts adjacent, re â¢ olved to put themÅ¿elves into a poÅ¿ture to receive his High â¢ eÅ¿Å¿e, & to entertain him with loyalty and h â¢ n â¢ ur, i â¢ he would be pleaÅ¿ed to entruÅ¿t his perÅ¿on in their hands, & to land only Å¿uch a party that did conÅ¿iÅ¿t of EngliÅ¿h, bu â¢ would not aÅ¿Å¿ent to the coming in of any Forreigners, conc â¢ iving the conÅ¿ â¢ quences to be very dangerous; the â¢ e â¢ o â¢ eÅ¿olved not to admit of any invaÅ¿i â¢ n by Å¿tr â¢ ngers: Whereupon, his HighneÅ¿Å¿e diÅ¿truÅ¿ting the event â¢ f his DeÅ¿ign,
called a generall Councell, aboard the Royall N â¢ vie, where was preÅ¿ent, his Highn â¢ Å¿Å¿e the D â¢ ke of York, Prince Rup â¢ rt, Prince Maurice, the Lord Culpepper, the Lord Gerrard, the Lord Willoughby of Parham, the Lord
â¢ ermin, the Lord Ruthin, Sir
â¢ ohn Bartley, and Col. Bainfield; and after Å¿ome conÅ¿ultation, in relation to their Landing, and Å¿erio â¢ Å¿ly of weighing, a â¢ d conÅ¿idering Å¿everall paticulars, which might prove very prejudicial and dangerous, to the Kings CauÅ¿e, they unanimouÅ¿ly reÅ¿olved to get what ProviÅ¿ions they could aboard, and to hoyÅ¿t Å¿ayle to flote upon the Neptune Seas towards the Downs, there to caÅ¿t Anchor for the preÅ¿ent, and to Å¿end an Invit â¢ tion to the KentiÅ¿hmen, to invite them to their aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance.

But we fear, that they have Å¿till an Eagles eye upon this County, and in regard Yarmouth lies Å¿o point blank for the Revolted Ships to come unto, it is feared, That if they Å¿hould poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e themÅ¿elves of the Å¿aid, That Å¿ome whiÅ¿perings, were amongÅ¿t them, in Relation to the Å¿aid DeÅ¿ign, and we conceive it probable, that had not Lovingland been Å¿ecured by Col. Scroop, and a Regiment of the County foot, they had poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed themÅ¿elves of that place ere this; for our Intelligencer Å¿aith, That it was the ReÅ¿olution, bo â¢ h of the Prince, the Duke, the Lord Culpepper, the Lord Gerrard, and the reÅ¿t of the EngliÅ¿h Gallants, attending his HighneÅ¿Å¿e; to make a Å¿hew at Yarmouth, and then to uÅ¿e their endeavours for the Å¿ecuring of the IÅ¿land of Lovingland, but by providence, it is now prevented; That which is moÅ¿t prevalent, and doth induce us, to give credence to the Å¿aid Report; is, BecauÅ¿e the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition and affection of the Inhabitants, are weaned from the
Parliament, and linked firme to the RoyaliÅ¿ts; for I cannot hear, that Å¿ince the begining of theÅ¿e Å¿ad times, of many Volunteers, that hath been Å¿et forth of that IÅ¿land for the Parliaments Å¿ervice. And for your further Å¿atisfactio â¢ touching the deÅ¿cription of the Å¿aid IÅ¿l â¢ nd, I Å¿hall here give you a brief account thereof, viZ. The PeninÅ¿ula of Lovingland, in the County of Suffolk, in Longitude extends it Å¿elfe 7. miles, in Latitude 4. It contains 16. PariÅ¿hes, abou â¢ ding with all things requirable either by neceÅ¿Å¿ity or delight, by way of Å¿uÅ¿tentation or recreation: Its bleÅ¿t with a healthfull Ayre, Å¿cituated for a generall accomodation of Trade, having the Sea bordering upon a fourth part of it; the other parts being begirt with the great Rivers of Yare and Waurney, by which the Country Commodities are brought into it, and from thence tranÅ¿ported to all tranÅ¿marine parts: The whole PeninÅ¿ula is ra â¢ Å¿ed into one intire Hill, defended tow â¢ rds the Sea; with Cliffs and Sands, and on all parts by Land Å¿urrounded with a Å¿pecious levell of low grounds, amidÅ¿t which levels runs the forenamed Rivers, diÅ¿charging themÅ¿elves into the Sea, through the Å¿aid IÅ¿land; So that it is invinÅ¿ible by land, four paÅ¿Å¿ages excepted, and one by Sea, called Newton Gap; It hath in former times been called by the name of Low-England; being as conÅ¿iderable a place for health, fortility, Å¿trength, and pleaÅ¿ure, as any that I know of within his MajeÅ¿ties Realms and Dominions; And if it Å¿hould be once loÅ¿t, it will not be vaÅ¿t Å¿ums and multitudes of lives that will regain it. It is Å¿aid that Prince Rupert had a great deÅ¿ire to l â¢ nd there, and had he â¢ ffected it, it would have hazarded the loÅ¿Å¿e of â¢ he whole Kingdom, For,

To maÅ¿ter EngliÅ¿hmen, muÅ¿t thankfull be,
to him that lets you Peace and perill Å¿ee.

div.p: The Romans having formerly gained this place, and tranÅ¿ported their Colonies, bridled the whole EaÅ¿t of England by it, and brought the people under Å¿ubjection. Thus having faithfully imparted, the proceedings of the Prince, and their ReÅ¿olution to have poÅ¿Å¿ â¢ Å¿Å¿ed themÅ¿elves of this IÅ¿land, I remain,

div.head: PropoÅ¿itions from his HighneÅ¿Å¿e the Princee of Wales, to be publiÅ¿hed to the Kingdom of England.
div.p: 1 That his HighneÅ¿Å¿e doth declare that the Reformation of Religion, Å¿hall be as it was agreed on with the Scots Dec. 26 laÅ¿t in the IÅ¿le of Wight.
2 To reÅ¿cue his Maj. from His impriÅ¿onment, that he may fit with the Parl. and enjoy his rights.
3 That the two HouÅ¿es of Parl. may be reÅ¿tored to their freedom.
4 That the Kingdom may be eaÅ¿ed of the ExciÅ¿e.
5 That the A â¢ my of Sectaries may be disbanded.
6 That all taxes and ceÅ¿Å¿ements may be taken off.
7 That the narrow Å¿eas may be protected, for the carrying on of a free trade in the paÅ¿Å¿age of Merchants Å¿hips.
8 That the City of London may enjoy their Priviledges and Rights.

div.head: From Dover CaÅ¿tle, July 29. 1648.
div.p: WEE have received Intelligence, of the incredible newes of the The ConÅ¿tant Warwick; Could it h â¢ ve been immagined, that two names moÅ¿t conÅ¿iÅ¿tent with change, Å¿hould have revolted; but it was carryed away by Captain Batten, that Å¿omthing, he is able to draw away Mahomet, and his Iron CheÅ¿t from the LoadÅ¿tone; The going away of this Ship Å¿eemes ominous to many; who therefore expect Å¿ome notable buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e; but what will the Revolted Ships do? land an Army, where is it? not the London March â¢ nts, that's dangerous at this time, Londoners eff â¢ ct nor to be hindered in Trade, touch their Copyhold, and they will move otherwaies.

By our Intelligence from the WeÅ¿t, it is advertiÅ¿ed. That there are Å¿everall Ships lies in the Harbours at PortÅ¿mouth, and in the IÅ¿le of Wyght, and that Å¿ome of the Seamen. begins to have revolting Language, and cryes out, Hey for King Charles and his Royall Ships, and Å¿ome of the Saylors which lay in PortÅ¿mouth Harbour, openly declared themÅ¿elves in the Town, in the like Å¿peeches; but Å¿ome of them were Å¿oone Å¿ilenced, and comm â¢ tted to Å¿afe CuÅ¿tody.

The Earl of Warwick hath 16. gallant Ships ready to put to Sea, victualled, and provided with all neceÅ¿Å¿aries whatÅ¿oever: The revolting and running away of the Seamen, after they have been lifted, hath much retarded the work in hand, His LordÅ¿hip leaves no meanes u â¢ aÅ¿Å¿ayed, to advance and further the CauÅ¿e, and encourage the Marreigners in this honorable Engagement, for the reducing of revolted Ships, whoÅ¿e deÅ¿ignes may be v â¢ ry deÅ¿tructive, both to King and Kingdom, if not timely prevented.

Walmer CaÅ¿tle is ready to attend the motion of â¢ he Prince, Deale is exce â¢ ding inÅ¿olent and Å¿tubborn, and does execu â¢ ion upon our men, the walles are thick, and Cannon-proofe, and have great advantage upon our men; but notwit â¢ Å¿ta â¢ ding, their opportunities, and advantages, our men are reÅ¿olute, and Col. Rich deports himÅ¿elfe with great gallantry, Major Husbands is likewiÅ¿e very forward and active, and upon Fryd â¢ y laÅ¿t, the beÅ¿ieged made a Å¿allcy, where he charged them with his own Troop, (who had then the Guard) diÅ¿puted the buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, put them to a retreat, and purÅ¿ued them to the very CaÅ¿tle Gates.
